items.title: A new challenger appears
items.content:
#â€‹678 â€” March 7, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸ“’ Â Eloquent JavaScript Goes Fourth â€” Coming several years after the third edition, the latest version of, perhaps, the best â€˜all rounderâ€™ book for learning JavaScript is here: â€œadjusted to the realities of 2024 and generally touched up.â€ You can read it on the Web, but itâ€™ll be available in print later onÂ too.

Marijn Haverbeke

Deno Introduces JSR: A New JavaScript Registry â€” The JavaScript Registry (a.k.a. JSR) is a new TypeScript-first, ESM-only module registry designed for the entire JavaScript ecosystem. This post digs into what itâ€™s all about and how it builds upon the success ofÂ npm.

Dahl, Casonato, and Whinnery

Advanced JavaScript Tools to Empower Your Applications â€” Build better web applications with powerful JavaScript developer tools including: SpreadJS Excel-like spreadsheet components, ActiveReportsJS reporting tools, Wijmo UI component suite, and Document Solutions viewers for PDF, Excel, Image, andÂ more.

MESCIUS inc sponsor

'Apple Backs Off Killing Web Apps, But The Fight Continues' â€” Last week, we linked to an open letter imploring Apple to reverse its moves around breaking PWAs.. and it worked? Whatever the case, Apple continues to seem hostile to developers, and there's more to be tackled in thisÂ area.

Open Web Advocacy

IN BRIEF:

  • JavaScript is the focus of a WIRED feature where the author ponders if JavaScript Runs the World â€“ Maybe Even Literally.

  • The OpenJS Foundation says we should care about package metadata interoperability and has put together a 'collab space' to focus onÂ it.

  • ğŸ“… This year's JSHeroes conference takes place in Romania on May 23-24.

  • Is client side security dead, or a critical part of the future? asks GalÂ Weizman.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v21.7 (Current) â€“ Node gains a built-in way to output colored text, load and parse environment variables, and support multi-line values in .envÂ files.

  • TypeScript 5.4 â€“ Improved type narrowing, the NoInfer utility type, Object.groupBy, Map.groupBy, andÂ more.

  • Mermaid 10.9Â â€“ Generate diagrams fromÂ text.

  • Bun v1.0.30, Vue Language Tools 2.0, Ember 5.7

Sentry Launch Week: Making Debugging Fun â€” Weâ€™ll be making debugging fun, raffling swag and talking about all things developer, every. single. day. (For oneÂ week.)

Sentry sponsor

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Ultimate Guide to Visual Testing with Playwright â€” â€˜Ultimateâ€™ is always a gamble in a title, but this tutorial is pretty thorough and will get you several steps down the road of fetching pages and making comparisons, all fromÂ JavaScript.

Mike Stop Continues (BrowserCat)

Streaming HTML Out of Order Without JavaScript? â€” An interesting, yet short and sweet, demo of a browser feature that enables a technique you may not have imagined possible without JavaScript â€“ note that support is still rather freshÂ inÂ Firefox.

Chris Haynes

Effortless GraphQL with Hasura and TypeScript Functions â€” Connect to your data sources, generate a GraphQL API, and deploy globally â€” instantly. Want to write and use TypesScript functions directly in your GraphQL API? With Hasura, you can. Check itÂ out.

Hasura sponsor

â–¶Â Â Drizzle ORM Explained in 100 Seconds â€” The latest bitesize video from the always educational Fireship channel covers Drizzle ORM, a fast, TypeScript-based way to work with a variety of database systems across numerous JavaScript platforms, from Node to Bun, Deno Deploy, Supabase Functions, Cloudflare Workers, and more. If you need more, thereâ€™s â–¶ï¸ a 13 minute â€˜crash courseâ€™ to learning Drizzle,Â too.

Fireship

Fireship has a â–¶ï¸ Expo in 100 seconds video out too, providing a rapid explanation of what the React Native-based toolkit isÂ about.

JavaScript Bloat in 2024 â€” Whatâ€™s the average size of JavaScript code downloaded per website? Spoiler alert: itâ€™s a lot and will make anyone from the 56k dialup daysÂ cry.

Nikita Prokopov

Tiny Predictive Text â€” Using 2MB of JavaScript with no AI or LLMs in sight (but using a variant of a MarkovÂ chain).

Adam Grant

Coroutines and Web Components â€” â€œWe will see how coroutines can be used to model web components in a different way, and why you might likeÂ it.â€

Laurent Renard

Using Web Bluetooth to Read BBQ Temperature Sensor Data
Rik Schennink

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Million Lint: A Linter for React Performance â€” Millionâ€™s mission is to make React apps faster and the new VS Code extension Million Lint takes a new approach: imagine ESLint but for suggesting performanceÂ improvements.

Aiden Bai

Your Google Translate for UI â†”ï¸ Code â€” Donâ€™t get lost in translation. Build UI with code and copy clean JSX off yourÂ design.

UXPin Merge sponsor

BlockNote 0.12: A 'Notion-Like' Block-Based Text Editor â€” 0.12.0 is a significant release for this ProseMirror and TipTap-based editor that lets you drag and drop blocks, add real-time collaboration, add customizable â€˜slash commandâ€™ menus, and more. It has an all new homepage, too, along with newÂ examples.

TypeCell

PixiJS v8: Build Striking 2D WebGL Experiences â€” PixiJS is a very mature, long standing rendering library that abstracts away all the pain of building fast 2D graphical experiences for the Web. v8 boasts significant performance improvements, a WebGPU-backed renderer, and a variety of API improvements. If youâ€™re new to Pixi, thereâ€™s an interactive tutorial to show you theÂ ropes.

PixiJS Team

NSFW JS 4.1: Client-Side Indecent Content Checking â€” A client-side TensorFlow.js-powered option for detecting potentially indecent images before they even go over the wire. Itâ€™s not fool proof but may help as another layer of protection for both you and your users. GitHubÂ repo.

Infinite Red, Inc.

Plotly 2.30: A JavaScript Graphing Library â€” A high-level, declarative charting library, built on top of D3 and stack.gl, with over 40 chart types, including 3D charts, statistical graphs, and SVGÂ maps.

Plotly, Inc.

ONBOARDING_LIB: A Headless Onboarding Library â€” An onboarding library for building accessible, customizable and persisted onboarding flows in React apps. The site itself is an example of such aÂ flow.

Neftic Oy

Finder 3.2: CSS Selector Generator â€” Given an element, it produces the shortest possible, but precise, selector that reaches thatÂ element.

Anton Medvedev

Set Your JavaScript Job Hunt on Autopilot â€” First 2 Apply automatically monitors most popular job sites and sends you instant notifications for new listings. Try it forÂ free.

First2Apply sponsor

  • Partytown 0.10.0 â€“ Move intensive third-party scripts off the main thread and into aÂ webÂ worker.

  • AdminJS 7.7 â€“ Automatic admin interface for Node.jsÂ apps.

  • visx 3.9 â€“ Airbnb's React-based visualizationÂ primitives.

  • NVM Desktop 3.2 â€“ GUI for Node VersionÂ Manager.

  • melonJS 17.0 â€“ Browser-based 2D gameÂ engine.

  • NodeBB 3.7 â€“ Node.js based forumÂ system.

items.title: Postgres in TypeScript
items.content:
#â€‹677 â€” February 29, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

PGlite: PostgreSQL in WebAssembly (and TypeScript) â€” People have brought Postgres into the browser before, albeit atop a Linux VM WASM layer. PGlite, however, packages a WASM build of Postgres into a TypeScript library that can be run in the browser or on Node.js or Bun and is only 3.7MB gzipped. You can play with a live deployment here.

ElectricSQL / Neon

JSR: What We Know So Far About Denoâ€™s New JS Package Registry â€” The Deno team is cooking up JSR (still behind a waitlist), a new JavaScript package registry (not merely a package management tool, like pnpm or Yarn) to address various npm limitations, including for Node users who don't even plan to useÂ Deno.

Sarah Gooding (Socket)

Practice Your JavaScript through Vanilla JS Projects â€” Join Anjana Vakil for this extensive video course on vanilla JavaScript projects. Tackle real-world tasks and learn how to use asynchronous JS, Browser APIs, the DOM, Node.js, GitHub Actions, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Parcel v2.12.0: Now with Bun-Style Macros â€” The popular zero-config build tool introduces support for bundle-time macros, such as those offered in Bun. The value returned by a macro is inlined into the bundle in place of the original call. Thereâ€™s also a new online REPL where you can play with Parcel in the browser with support for most of Parcelâ€™sÂ features.

Parcel.js

IN BRIEF:

  • TypeScript 5.4 RC has been released, packing lots of small changes, as well as Object.groupBy, Map.groupBy, and type narrowingÂ enhancements.

  • Christopher Chedeau (aka Vjeux) has written about his 12 years at Meta, including being involved in the early days of both React and React Native.

  • A summary of recent updates to the V8 JavaScriptÂ engine.

  • ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º Fed up with Apple's nonsense around removing PWA support in the European Union? Open Web Advocacy has an open letter you canÂ co-sign.

RELEASES:

  • Express.js 4.18.3 â€“ The first release in sixteen months.Â ğŸ˜

  • Deno 1.41 â€“ Now with much smaller deno compile binary sizes, official Linux ARM64 binaries, and improvements to Node.js compatibility.

  • Playwright 1.42 â€“ Browser remote control and runnerÂ toolkit.

  • Babel 7.24.0 â€“ Supports importing JSON modules and updates its DecoratorsÂ implementation.

  • TinyMCE 7.0 â€“ Rich text editor component â€“ now GPLÂ licensed.

Frontend Developer ğŸ” (Fully Remote ğŸŒ Or In Our Office In Stockholm, Sweden ğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ª) â€” Do you get excited when you hear Next.js, Supabase, GraphQL? Letâ€™sÂ talk.
ZCO Stockholm job

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Reporting Core Web Vitals with the Performance API â€” The Performance API provides an interface to ways to measure and evaluate Web performance metrics from JavaScript. Geoff demonstrates how to use its capabilities to do your own performanceÂ reporting.

Geoff Graham

A Fun Line of JavaScript Code â€” Namely, using Promise.race to search through audio files forwards and backwards at the same time and stop as soon as the relevant metadata isÂ found.

David Bushell

How StackBlitz Built a T-Shirt That Renders Itself â€” How we designed a t-shirt using valid JavaScript that is also the source code of the image itself (and how you can getÂ one).

StackBlitz sponsor

Next.js vs. Remix: A Developer's Dilemma â€” Compares a variety of areas, from how various techniques are implemented through to deployment, support, andÂ popularity.

Chetan Gawai

Why Does is-number Have 70+ Million Weekly Downloads? â€” In part, itâ€™s included in a chain of dependencies used by a very popularÂ project.

Shubham Jain

17 Equations That Changed the World - Rewritten in JavaScript â€” This is quite neat if you enjoy a bit ofÂ math.

RunJS

How to Create Sidebar Navigation with Astro, Tailwind CSS and Alpine.js
Michael Andreuzza

â–¶Â Â Use AWS Amplify Gen 2 to Create a Full Stack App with Type Safety
Erik Hanchett (AWS)

A Look into JSDoc as an Alternative TypeScript Syntax
Alex Harri

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

PrimeVue 3.49.0: Vue UI Component Library â€” A mature, rich set of open source UI components for Vue developers we first mentioned a few years ago. This new release includes components to enter one time passwords and a â€˜stepperâ€™ for wizard-style workflows. Thereâ€™s also a new optional declarative syntax for using components that makes their code easier to read andÂ write.

PrimeTek

Authentication & User Management for the Modern Web â€” Add authentication & user management easily with Clerk using our Quickstart guides. Purpose-built for React &Â Next.js.

Clerk sponsor

Waku: A Minimal Server-Side React Framework â€” From the maintainer of Jotai, Valtio, and Zustand, Waku is a lighter alternative to something like Next.js but that still opens up the potential of server components, shared components, and elegant routing, in a simpler, easier to applyÂ way.

Daishi Kato

Embla Carousel 8: Carousel with Fluid Motion and 'Swipe Precision' â€” Carousels are a popular, though often maligned, UI element, but the examples work pretty well for us. Library agnostic, but has easy integrations for React, Solid, and Angular, if you needÂ them. The v8.0 release notes touch on many newÂ features.

David Jerleke

Readability.js: Extract the Readable Content from an HTML Document â€” A standalone version of the library used to power Firefoxâ€™s ReaderÂ View. It's been a few years since we've linked to this, but it continues to beÂ improved.

Mozilla

Viz.js: Work with Graphviz in the Browser â€” Graphviz is a suite of open source graph drawing tools of some 30+ yearsâ€™ vintage. Viz.js is a WebAssembly Graphviz build that brings some of its functionality into the browser, as seen in the homepage's live demo (above). GitHubÂ repo.

Michael Daines

ğŸ¨Â Vue Color Wheel: A Wheel-Style Color Picker for Vue 3 â€” Far from a new idea, but elegantly demonstrated on itsÂ homepage. Coloris is a nice, vanilla alternative in this space, if the wheel view isn't aÂ necessity.

Robert Shaw

Neon is Postgres from the Future â€” Scales to zero when idle, autoscales based on load, provisions instantly. Generous free tier - no credit cardÂ required.

Neon Serverless Postgres sponsor

WXT: Next-Gen Web Extension Framework â€” A framework for creating cross-browser extensions. You can target Chrome, Firefox, Edge and Safari. Plasmo is another option in thisÂ space.

WXT

  • React Strict DOM (RSD) â€“ An experimental integration of React DOM and StyleX to standardize the development of styled React components, both web andÂ native.

  • ğŸ—“ React Date Picker 6.2 â€“ Simple date picker component.Â (Demo.)

  • webdav-client 5.4 â€“ WebDAV client library for Node &Â browsers.

  • Jotai 2.7 â€“ Simple, flexible state management forÂ React.

  • ğŸ¹ JZZ 1.8 â€“ MIDI library for Node andÂ browsers.

  • RxDB 15.10 â€“ Offline-first, reactiveÂ database.

  • Bun 1.0.29 â€“ Minor enhancements.

Jotai 2.7 â€“ Simple, flexible state management forÂ React.
ğŸ¹ JZZ 1.8 â€“ MIDI library for Node andÂ browsers.
RxDB 15.10 â€“ Offline-first, reactiveÂ database.
Bun 1.0.29 â€“ Minor enhancements.

items.title: A big update for ECharts
items.content:
#â€‹676 â€” February 22, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸ“ŠÂ Apache ECharts 5.5: The Powerful Visualization Library â€” EChartsâ€™ big selling point, beyond being a well supported Apache-backed project, is its balance of power and simplicity. You can do a lot with it (check out the many examples here) without the code becoming complex. v5.5 enhances its ESM support, adds server-side rendering support, and lets you make incomplete pieÂ charts.

Apache Software Foundation

ğŸ’Œ If you need to be convinced further, check out Alice GG's Love Letter to ApacheÂ ECharts.

ğŸ“£Â The React Team Shares What It's Been Working On â€” Work on React Compiler has progressed with it now powering Instagramâ€™s prod site ('React 19 Will Be Compiled' goes into depth on what the compiler means for most React devs). We also learn React 19 is on the way and will include breaking changes to support things like WebÂ Components.

The React.js Core Team

Register for POST/CON 24! Coming April 30-MayÂ 1 â€” Join hundreds of developers in San Francisco on April 30 and May 1 for hands-on API workshops, presentations from industry leaders, and a big reveal of Postman productÂ updates.

Postman sponsor

Redwood v7.0: The React + GraphQL App Framework â€” Redwood is a full-stack Web framework that takes an opinionated approach, bringing together React, GraphQL, Prisma, and TypeScript, with a focus on building complete apps rapidly. v7 includes a new observability tool called Redwood Studio, realtime GraphQL features, andÂ more.

RedwoodJS Community

Node.js's 2023 Summarized â€” Rafael, of the Node.js TSC and Fastify core team, shares a useful update on the evolution of Node.js over the past year, how the team ensures Node is well tested and reliable, changes to Nodeâ€™s vendor dependencies (of which it gained three in 2023), as well as enhancements to Nodeâ€™s security and WebÂ presence.

Rafael Gonzaga

IN BRIEF:

  • ğŸ¢Â The Node.js project has unveiled Rocket Turtle, its new mascot!

  • 1 in 5 of the most popular, 'high impact' packages on npm now includeÂ ESM.

  • ğŸ‘¾ A 'Frogger' game in 256 bytes? Yes, really. Be sure to ViewÂ Source.

  • A visualization of Math.random() distributions of variousÂ kinds.

  • The Deno team has revamped its onboarding tutorials for Deno Deploy, if you want to experiment with JavaScript at the edge.

RELEASES:

  • Bun 1.0.28 â€“ Mostly a bugfix/stabilityÂ release.

  • Puppeteer 22.2 â€“ Control Chrome with Node.js. Now on Chrome 122.

  • Deno 1.41, Rollup 4.12.0, Jest Puppeteer 10.0

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

A Guide to Using localStorage in Modern Apps â€” localStorage has been supported in most browsers for fifteen years plus now, so itâ€™s a reliable way to store data client-side, though there are still situations where you wouldnâ€™t want to use it. A good primer, but with a focus on alternativeÂ options.

RxDB Project

How to Set Up a Basic Node Server App with TypeScript in 2024 â€” Popular dev educator Jason with a quick tutorial on how to set up a modern Node project with TypeScript, live reloading, and loading in environmentÂ variables.

Jason Lengstorf

Transformational Auth & Identity | Userfront â€” Userfront is an auth & identity platform that transforms your business to serve free, freemium and enterpriseÂ customers.

Userfront sponsor

â–¶Â Â Pac-Man in JavaScript in 1 Hour â€” I felt old when Ania said â€œif youâ€™ve never played Pac-Man before..â€ ğŸ˜… â€“ nonetheless, sheâ€™s back with another of her fantastic, thoroughÂ walkthroughs.

Ania KubÃ³w

HTMX vs React: A Complete Comparison â€” It strikes me as tricky to compare two very different approaches to what will often be distinct use cases, but undoubtedly people will want to weigh them up against each other, so here youÂ go.

Antonello Zanini and Dan Ackerson

How Qwik Differs From React Hydration â€” Qwik works quite differently to the ReactÂ approach.

Paul Scanlon (The New Stack)

An Ultimate Vim Vue Setup â€” How to set up Vue/Nuxt autocompletion forÂ Vim/Neovim.
Nikola Äuza

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Perspective 2.8: Fast Streaming Data Visualization via WebAssembly â€” A data visualization component, well-suited for large and/or streaming datasets, that can be used from both JavaScript and Python. Itâ€™s been fun watching this library improve over the past couple of years. The docs have been improved a lot. GitHubÂ repo.

Perspective Authors

Hookdeck: The Amazon EventBridge Alternative â€” Receive, send, and route messages across your event-driven applications with an event gateway for engineeringÂ teams.

Hookdeck sponsor

Vuestic Admin: A Vue 3 Admin Template â€” A recently redesigned, modern admin template using Vue 3, Vite, Pinia, and Tailwind CSS. Check out the live demo or GitHubÂ repo.

Epicmax LLC

ğŸ—“Â Tommy's Inclusive Datepicker: A Human-Friendly Date Picker â€” Try out this Web Component on the homepage itself. The user can type natural language phrases like â€œNext Fridayâ€ or â€œin 30 daysâ€ and the picker will move to the correct date. GitHubÂ repo.

Tommy Feldt

Skeleton: Reactive, Accessible Svelte UI Toolkit â€” A cool feature of the homepage is you can try out the different built-in themes, including dark and light modes, using a drop-down at theÂ top.

Skeleton Labs

Dax: Cross-Platform Shell Tools for Node â€” Similar to Google's zx but uses a cross-platform shell with common built-in commands so more code will work across platforms. Dax was originally written for Deno but now supports NodeÂ too.

David Sherret

js-tokens 9.0: A Tiny JavaScript Tokenizer â€” A regex-powered â€˜almost spec-compliantâ€™ JavaScriptÂ tokenizer.

Simon Lydell

A Sudoku Solver Implemented in the TypeScript Type System? â€” An appropriate use of the ğŸ¤¯ emojiÂ here, IÂ think!

Roy Li

Save 30% on Your POST/CON Ticket â€” Time is running out to save 30% on POST/CON 24. Don't miss out on Postmanâ€™s biggest user conferenceÂ ever.

Postman sponsor

  • Forge 7.3 â€“ Quickly scaffold an Electron project with full buildÂ pipeline.

  • eslint-plugin-check-file 2.7 â€“ Enforce consistent file/folderÂ naming.

  • React Native Boilerplate 4.1 â€“ A starter template for RNÂ apps.

  • React Uploady 1.8 â€“ Components and hooks for fileÂ uploading.

  • d3-graphviz 5.3 â€“ Graphviz DOT rendering and animatedÂ transitions.

  • ğŸ“± React Native Vision Camera 3.9 â€“ Powerful cameraÂ control.

  • âˆ Peaks.js 3.3 â€“ BBC-created audio waveform UIÂ component.

  • AdminJS 7.6 â€“ Automatic admin interface for NodeÂ apps.

items.title: TC39 adds a new stage for ECMAScript proposals
items.content:
#â€‹675 â€” February 15, 2024

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Tempo: An Easier Way to Work with Dates â€” We think they nailed their own summary: â€œA collection of utilities for working with the native Date object â€” an important distinction from other libraries that provide custom date primitives. Under the hood, Tempo mines Intl.DateTimeFormat to extract complex data like timezones offsets and locale aware date formats, giving you a simple API to format, parse, and manipulate dates.â€ Fantastic docs,Â too.

FormKit

LLRT (Low Latency Runtime): Amazon's New JSÂ Runtime â€” Amazon has open sourced a runtime entirely focused on fast startups â€“ something thatâ€™s useful for ephemeral use cases like serverless (*cough* AWS Lambda). It uses Fabrice Bellardâ€™s QuickJS as the underlying engine, so has almost full ES2023 spec support out of theÂ box.

Amazon Web Services Labs

Effortless GraphQL with Hasura and TypeScript Functions â€” Hasura connects to your data sources, generates a GraphQL API, and deploys it globally â€” instantly. But, what if you could also write and use TypesScript functions directly in your GraphQL API? With Hasura, you can. Check it out onÂ GitHub.

Hasura sponsor

The Node.js Valentine's Day Security Releases â€” Security releases had been expected to land in the past week for Node and theyâ€™re now here as v21.6.2 (Current), v20.11.1 (LTS), and v18.19.1 (LTS). They include fixes for a variety of vulnerabilities, including some high severity ones involving HTTP-based DoS attacks and privilegeÂ escalation.

Rafael Gonzaga and Marco Ippolito

IN BRIEF:

  • You know how features and proposals for the ECMAScript language pass through a multi-stage process with the TC39 committee? There's a new stage: stage 2.7! The new stage is what 3 used to be with 3 now having extra testingÂ requirements.

  • Talking of TC39, here's the latest state of different proposals covered at the recent 100th TC39Â meeting.

  • There have been some updates on the state of Express and suggested plans for Express 5.0, 6.0 andÂ 7.0.

  • Google has unveiled the newest version of its Gemini AI model. Of particular note is its support for 1 million tokens of context, as shown in â–¶ï¸ this example working upon the entirety of three.js's source code (~820kÂ tokens).

  • A new JavaScript registry is on the way called jsr. Waitlist only, forÂ now.

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

RELEASES:

  • Vue.js DevTools 6.6 â€“ Now with a new UI.

  • Hono 4.0 â€“ The lightweight, runs-anywhere Web framework takes a big stepÂ forward.

  • JointJS 4.0 â€“ The powerful interactive diagramming/flowchart library now has no externalÂ dependencies.

  • Astro 4.4, Angular 17.2, Billboard.js 3.11

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Union, Intersection, Difference, and More Coming to JavaScript Sets â€” Set was introduced back in ECMAScript 2015 (a.k.a. ES6) but only had some basic methods built-in. Phil looks at what sets can do and what new features are on theÂ way.

Phil Nash

Immutable Array Updates with Array.prototype.with â€” How to use this new, widely supported method to update an array without mutating the originalÂ array.

Jad Joubran

Intro to Error and Performance Monitoring with Sentry â€” Track, trace, debug and resolve JavaScript errors across platforms. Are your releases that easy? Join usÂ live.

Sentry sponsor

â–¶Â Â So You Think You Know Git.. â€” GitHub co-founder Scott Chacon gave a spirited talk at FOSDEM 2024 digging into many interesting parts of git, as well as a few GitHub bits. If youâ€™d prefer to read rather than watch, he has some blog posts covering it allÂ too.

Scott Chacon

An Example of Creating a React App with Google Sheets as aÂ Backend â€” Not as unorthodox an approach as you mightÂ think.

Musthaq Ahamad

Safely Accessing the DOM with Angular SSR â€” Learn how to safely use the DOM together with SSR inÂ Angular.

Gerald Monaco (Google)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Peggy 4.0: A Parser Generator for JavaScript â€” Produces fast parsers with good error reporting. Use it to process complex data or computer languages and build transformers, interpreters, compilers, and similar tools. The online demo is pretty effective. The official successor to PEG.js.

Majda, Hildebrand, and Contributors

vue-metamorph 1.0: A Codemod Framework for Vue.js Projects â€” A developer needed to make a large number of small changes to a variety of Vue components and built this tool to help. GitHubÂ repo.

UnrefinedBrain

canvas-size 2.0: Determine Max Area, Height, Width, and Custom Dimensions of HTML Canvases â€” The Canvas element is broadly supported across browsers but there are differences in its size limitations, which this library can determine for you. GitHubÂ repo.

John Hildenbiddle

Securing Your APIs: Verifying API Keys And Using Scopes â€” You have APIs. You need to make sure you know who is calling them and what they can do. What are yourÂ options?

FusionAuth sponsor

txiki.js: A Small Yet Powerful JavaScript Runtime â€” Standing on the shoulders of QuickJS andÂ libuv.

SaÃºl Ibarra CorretgÃ©

Svelte Stepper: Build Animated Stepped Flows with Svelte â€” You can add and customize props on the component to adjust the number of steps and transition duration, among other features. See a simple but neat demoÂ here.

Jason Efstathiou

  • ğŸ™ˆ NSFW.js 3.0 â€“ Client-side NSFW image detection viaÂ TensorFlow.js.

  • ğŸ—“ React Big Calendar 1.10 â€“ GCal/Outlook-like calendarÂ component.

  • Tedious 17.0 â€“ TDS module for connecting to Microsoft SQLÂ Server.

  • Inspire Tree 7.0 â€“ Perf-driven headless treeÂ component.

  • Heat.js 2.1 â€“ Render customizable heatÂ maps.

  • Mineflayer 4.19 â€“ Create Minecraft bots inÂ JavaScript.

  • Spacetime 7.6 â€“ Lightweight timezoneÂ library.

  • React Tags 6.9 â€“ TaggingÂ component.

title: JavaScript Weekly
description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects
